body:
The `*interface{}` pattern looks unnatural to me. `map[string]interface{}` would be better suited for that case. Problem is that introducing this as a general behavior brings quite some breaking change (see also https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/issues/1450).

You may work around the issue by declaring your type as:
```yaml
            type: object
            required:
              - "value"
            properties:
              value:
                type: object
                additionalProperties: true
                description: no problem
                example: 1
```

issue.title: Client generation using definition x-go-type in Body

labels.name: model
labels.description: Related to swagger generate model command

issue.body:
## Problem statement
When I generate client including a definition with x-go-type in Body, the code doesn't compile at 
https://github.com/kathra-project/kathra-resourcemanager-client-go/blob/238c2673ed03f0a60b148daf0abd592980483fdc/client/users/add_user_parameters.go#L129
The message : cannot convert nil to type models.User

Because structs generated for parameters contain body properties as value, not a pointer.
https://github.com/kathra-project/kathra-resourcemanager-client-go/blob/238c2673ed03f0a60b148daf0abd592980483fdc/client/users/add_user_parameters.go#L70

## Swagger specification
Specs for client : https://gitlab.com/kathra/specifications/raw/feature/catalogManager/Services/catalogmanager/swagger.yaml
Specs for model : https://gitlab.com/kathra/specifications/raw/feature/catalogManager/Services/core/swagger.yaml

## Environment
swagger version: 0.21.0
go version: 1.13.3
OS: Ubuntu 19.06

issue.title: importing struct with x-go-type generates client code which doesnt compile

labels.name: model
labels.description: Related to swagger generate model command

issue.body:
## Problem statement
i'm trying to extract a model from our swagger document & consume it from an external source. we want the the type to be generated by DB access layer which also has a schema & generates code.

when doing so i've hit 2 issues:
1. The API's which use the imported types changed so that they take a value rather than a pointer. this implies most of the called API's which forces a huge change to the code base.
Notet hat the type definition has changed a bit - its the exact same definition when comparing the generated go code using diff tool.
That's the simple one :)

2. some API's which take a type T imported using the x-go-type now generate invalid code for the client.
these API's consume the imported type within the API body. they generate the type as value rather than pointer but still check for it to be nil, which fails to compile.
so having a workaround to make the value back into a pointer would be a work-around.
 

## Swagger specification
the part which imports the type looks like so:
```
Hotspot:
  x-go-type:
    import:
      package: fbc/xwf/swagger/gen/ents
    type: Hotspot
  x-nullable: true
```

The API declaration (schema version 2.0) is:
```
post:
  tags:
  - hotspot
  summary: Create a Hotspot
  operationId: "CreateHotspot"
  consumes:
  - application/json
  produces:
  - application/json
  parameters:
  - in: body
    name: Hotspot
    required: false
    schema:
      $ref: '#/definitions/Hotspot'
  responses:
    201:
      description: Hotspot created.
      schema:
        $ref: '#/definitions/Hotspot'
    400:
      description: Bad request.
      schema:
        $ref: '#/definitions/Error'
    422:
      description: Unprocessable entity
      schema:
        $ref: '#/definitions/Error'
    500:
      description: Unexpected error.
      schema:
        $ref: '#/definitions/Error'
```

## Steps to reproduce
generating client code generates the following invalid code:

```
func (o *CreateHotspotParams) WriteToRequest(r runtime.ClientRequest, reg strfmt.Registry) error {

        if err := r.SetTimeout(o.timeout); err != nil {
                return err
        }
        var res []error

        if o.Hotspot != nil {                   <<<<<<<<<<<<<<< This fails to compile. o.Hotspot is a value, NOT a pointer
                if err := r.SetBodyParam(o.Hotspot); err != nil {
                        return err
                }
        }

        if len(res) > 0 {
                return errors.CompositeValidationError(res...)
        }
        return nil
}
```


## Environment
swagger version: v0.21.0
commit: 7c0fc3ee340f9d99d85573bc54a57e303a639692  
go version: go1.13.5 darwin/amd64
OS:   MacOS Mojave, 10.14.6

issue.title: Setting additionalProperties: true does not generate map[string]interface{}

labels.name: model
labels.description: Related to swagger generate model command

issue.body:
## Problem statement

I specify a definition to be of type object with additionalProperties: true. I expect the generated client model to be of type map[string]interface{}. I see the resulting model instead has type interface{}

I would like to have a model generated as a type of map[string]interface{}, as I would like to define member functions on top of this model and cannot if it is of type interface{}

I have tried with 0.22, 0.23, and 0.17, but I continue to see this issue.

While changing it to
```
type: "object"
additionalProperties:
  type: "object"
```
does generate a map[string]interface{}, this is incompatible with the server definition as it is using javascript's swagger and will expect the values of each key to themselves be JSON, but my target is to have the values be any type. So I would like `additionalProperties: true` to generate map[string]interface{} so the client and server do not have contention issues.

I expected the behavior of map[string]interface{} given the following resources:
The documentation suggests this is the way to do it: https://goswagger.io/use/models/schemas.html (Ctrl+F for "additionalProperties: true", and it has an example suggesting that the addition of this causes the generated code to have the type map[string]interface{})
https://goswagger.io/faq/faq_model.html (Also says that if I add additionalProperties: true it will generate a map[string]interface{})

In addition, the following tickets all suggest this is a valid method of achieving the desired result:
https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/issues/1450#issuecomment-385613822 (not stated outright but that is how I understood this comment)
https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/issues/2081#issuecomment-541296380


## Swagger specification
```
swagger: "2.0"
info:
  version: "1.0.0"
  title: "Swagger Petstore"
host: "petstore.swagger.io"
basePath: "/v2"
paths:
  /pet:
    post:
      operationId: "addPet"
      parameters:
      - in: "body"
        name: "body"
        schema:
          $ref: "#/definitions/Pet"
      responses:
        "405":
          description: "Invalid input"
definitions:
  Pet:
    type: "object"
    additionalProperties: true
```
## Steps to reproduce
```
$ go-swagger generate client -t <outputDir> -f <aboveSnippet>
$ cat <outputDir>/models/pet.go
// Code generated by go-swagger; DO NOT EDIT.

package models

// This file was generated by the swagger tool.
// Editing this file might prove futile when you re-run the swagger generate command

// Pet pet
// swagger:model Pet
type Pet interface{}
```

I expect that since the Pet definition has `additionalProperties: true`, that the resulting model would be `type Pet map[string]interface{}`, not `type Pet interface{}`

## Environment
swagger version: 0.22.0  
go version: 1.13.1  
OS:  MacOS High Sierra/Darwin

issue.title: Fixed missing Required validations
issue.body:
Addresses missing "required" validation in some cases:
- when schema is mapped as an interface{} (e.g. additionalProperties: true)
- when schema is a mapped as a map[string]interface{} (e.g. additionalProperties: type: object)
- when schema is an aliased primitive type produced by a $ref

We compare the value to nil instead of calling `validate.Required()` whenever the type is `interface{}`.
Same for `validate.IsZero()`.

* fixes #2081 [required interface{}]
* fixes #2300 [required map[string]interface{}]
* fixes #2381 [required ref'ed primitive]
* fixes #2415 [duplicate of #2300]

Signed-off-by: Frederic BIDON <fredbi@yahoo.com>
